newsitem.title: JAPAN: DuPont-Mitsui polyethylene plant to restart by Wed.
newsitem.headline: DuPont-Mitsui polyethylene plant to restart by Wed.

text.p: DuPont-Mitsui Polychemical Co Ltd said on Tuesday it would restart its polyethylene plant in Hiroshima Prefecture, western Japan, by Wednesday. The plant has been closed since a fire earlier this month.
DuPont-Mitsui Polychemical is equally owned by DuPont KK, a Japanese subsidiary of DuPont Co, and Mitsui Petrochemical Industries Ltd.
"We will be bringing the plant back on line later today or tomorrow, now that we have received permission from local authorities for the restart," a company spokesman said.
The plant was shut on April 4 after vapourised ethylene, which was released from safety valves after pressure built up inside a reactor, caught fire.
No one was injured and no facilities were damaged by the fire.
The Hiroshima plant, which has the capacity to produce 70,000 tonnes of polyethylene a year, procures feedstock ethylene from Mitsui Petrochemical's Chiba plant near Tokyo.
